awd_titl_txt: Space Weather Research at the Jicamarca Radio Observatory
awd_abstract_narration:
This grnat seeks funds to renew support for research and operation of Jicamarca Radio Observatory (JRO) between January 1 2018 to December 31, 2022. JRO is situated on the magnetic equator, a prime location for studying the ionosphere from plasma backscatter. The observatory's main asset is a 50 MHz VHF radar system with an antenna consisting of 18,432 cross-polarized half-wavelength dipoles. The antenna system can be subdivided, steered, and attached to up to four transmitters and sixteen receivers. JRO's exceptional versatility has defined the facility as a testbed of radio science innovation and discovery.

The radar measures electron  density, electron and ion temperature, ion composition and vertical and zonal electric fields in the equatorial ionosphere. JRO also measuring echoes from equatorial irregularities generated in the troposphere, stratosphere, mesosphere, equatorial electrojet, E and F regions. In accordance with guidelines provided by a number of geospace community documents, the research activities will focus on topside ionosphere, high-altitude scattering, vertical (perpendicular to B) measurements, aperature-synthesis imaging, mesosphere-lower thermosphere winds, and space weather forecasting. JRO will continue its tradition as a center of training and education for an international community of physics and engineering students.

por.por_cntn:
The Jicamarca Radio Observatory is one of the largest radars in the world and the premiere facility for studying the earth's upper atmosphere and ionosphere near the magnetic equator. This is crucial as a number of space weather phenomena proliferate near the equatorial zone, posing hazards for various kinds of space-based systems including communication, navigation, and imaging systems. We study the equatorial ionosphere to gain a better understanding of the background dynamics, energetics, and transport in the region as well as of the associated space-weather phenomena, their effects, and ways of anticipating, exploiting, and mitigating them.

This was a five-year award for a research program carried out at Jicamarca. The program included regular and specialized operations of the Jicamarca radar to meet the research needs of the community, the development of new radar methods and modes for targeted investigations, upgrades meant to keep the facility contemporary, and regular maintenance, which can be daunting in view of the size and scope of the facility.

Scientific accomplishments of the Jicamarca facility are documented in the peer-reviewed publications arising from the work supported there in the past five years which number 100+. Just a few of the discoveries and developments are highlighted in this report below.

One recurring area of research at Jicamarca is so-called "equatorial spread F" or "ESF," an umbrella term referring to the spontaneous generation of broadband plasma density irregularities in the postsunset F region. These irregularities act as a diffraction screen, interfering with radio waves propagating through them. While ESF has been known about for almost a century, and while much of the fundamental physics involved has been understood since the 1970s, research at Jicamarca produced direct numerical simulations of the phenomena which form the basis for a forecast method. Practical ESF forecast tools are now under development.

Jicamarca research also produced the discovery of something entirely new -- a class of plasma density irregularities that form at night in the nighttime topside ionosphere and inner plasmasphere at an altitude of about 2000 km. The irregularities are common during solar minimum and are distinguished by Doppler shifts near the lower-hybrid frequency for hydrogen ions.  Research by a Ph.D. student at Cornell showed that the irregularities may be due to a class of lower hybrid drift instabilities. The source of free energy for the instabilities is residual seed irregularities deposited into the topside by ESF.

Another novel development at Jicamarca was the ability to measure incoherent scatter (ISR or collective Thomson scatter) using the small AMISR-14 UHF radar deployed at Jicamarca adjacent to the main VHF radar. That usable ISR spectra could be obtained with such a small system was not anticipated and suggests that similar, small radars could be deployed widely and economically at other sites around the world.  Complementing UHF with VHF signals at Jicamarca yields insights into enigmatic plasma instabilities, notably the instabilities responsible for so-called "150-km" echoes, as well as the fundamental physics of collective Thomson scatter at small magnetic aspect angles. Both of these topics are now frontier research areas in equatorial aeronomy.

Two important upgrades were performed at Jicamarca, bringing the system into the 21st century. One of these was the incorporation of electronic beam steering into the main phased array antenna which previously could only be steered using laborious and time-consuming manual recabling. Electronic beam steering allows the accumulation of observations in different ISR modes nearly simultaneously, an essential capability for comprehensive ionospheric research. Electronic beam steering also increased the efficiency of the radar which is essential for the most demanding experiments including planetary and solar radar experiments.

Another groundbreaking upgrade was the installation of two medium-power (100 kW) solid-state amplifiers in the transmitter chains. These transmitters are powerful enough for ISR experiments but reliable and economical enough to be run for long time intervals with minimal human intervention. The new amplifiers facilitate extremely long experimental runs which are required for synoptic studies of the ionosphere as well as for observing solar and geomagnetic storms. Novel research concerning the effects of geomagnetic substorms on equatorial electrodynamics benefit enormously from the new medium-power mode initiated during this research award.

Throughout the award, Jicamarca conducted two professional development and training programs meant to keep the pipeline of scientists and engineers with expertise in radar and ionospheric physics populated. One of these programs was directed toward undergraduate engineering students and the other toward graduate students.  Student projects stemmed from some of the aforementioned hardware and software upgrades and research projects.
